prompt: Create a poem about brown butter in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
Brown Butterwocky

It bubbled-brim, the buttergold,
Did fizzle-foom upon the flame;
All nutterbright the panlings rolled,
And brownsome specks took caramel-name.

Beware the Burniburn, dear cook!
Beware the bitter-scorch and smoke!
Shun splutterspry from foamy brook,
The spit and snap the skillet spoke!

He seized his whiskerwhirligy;
Long time the melt-quest there he sought;
He watched the foam turn milk-snowy,
And sniffed the toast of browning thought.

And, as he hovered, stovetop-glow,
The Brown Butterwock drew near;
It hummed a hazel, nutter-low,
A toastish song for cookish ear.

Flip-whirl! Stir-turn! The whisk did dance;
He skimmed the specks that twirl and gleam;
Through golden swales and amber trance,
He shepherded the sizzling stream.

O triumphbright! O toastsome bliss!
He sluiced it over noodlenests;
It kissed sage leaves with buttery kiss,
And wooed the dough in cookie chests.

Yet mind the scorchling’s shadow-creep,
Shun bitter-bane and ashy blame;
Keep watchful ward while bubbles sleep,
Then whisk it off the eager flame.

It bubbled-brim, the buttergold,
Now purls at rest from embered heat;
All nutterbright the kitchen-hold,
And brownborn dreams grow caramel-sweet.

prompt: Write a poem about creep in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Crindle-Creep

’Twas drizzle-dim in Drindle Dell,
where flannelwinds went nip and neep;
the mullen-grass began to swell,
for through the roots there oozed the Creep.

“Mind well the Creep, my sprindle child—
the long-along with hushy tread!
It sours the beams and smarms the tiled,
and weighs your hours like noodle lead.

“It softens steel to taffy-strings,
it droops the rafters, bend by bend;
it gnaws the glue of homely things
and pulls the now toward the end.”

I took my twibble-tempered blade,
my tick-tack shield of spring and sproke;
I sought it where the joists had swayed,
among the knurls of wrinkled oak.

And there it dribbled, slow and sly—
a lollop lump of leak and seep;
with velvet-weights behind its eye,
it sighed and lengthened—Creep by creep.

We waltzed a while in viscous air;
I chopped its ooze to flinder-fleck—
but every slice grew long and spare
and slumped again about my neck.

So then I learned the twindle art:
brace beams and cinch the sleep of eaves;
tie knot to knot the trembling heart
and oil the hinge that slowly heaves.

Now drizzle-bright in Drindle Dell,
the rafters hum; the clocks keep keep;
yet under floorboards, hush and swell,
it bides, it bides—the Crindle-Creep.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on awl in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Awl-Whicker

Squin-twilight chimed the tatterhour,
and seamwinds snuffled through the hides;
All stitchly bloomed the cobbler-flower,
as puckerlings took prickle strides.

"Grip-close the awl," old Stitcher crooned,
"that burin-beak, that bristle spark!
It pecks a path where leather-mooned,
and opens day from seamed-up dark.

"Bewink thy thumb, keep nerves in thrall,
and mind the nip of needle bite;
For gentle seems the little awl,
yet pricks the world to set it right."

So palm to haft and thumb to guard,
he held the prinkle-poking tool;
Its pebbled hilt was knurled and hard,
its point a star that kept its cool.

He sought the Rippery Raveled Rift,
where scrap and skelp in shadow stall;
He heard the snick of threadward lift—
the pick-pick rhyme of Awl-of-All.

Click-crick! the riven gap drew near,
loop-kissed by loops in nimble rows;
The rent unteethed its jag of fear,
and hummed itself to pucker prose.

He stitched the dusk to dawning seam,
he laced the hides of hush and din;
The world, once torn, lay glove-precise,
and wore its weather smooth again.

Back home he set the awl to rest,
its beak asleep in oily grain;
And tatterhour, well-mended, blessed
the prick that made it whole again.

prompt: Create a poem about third rail hum in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Third-Rail Thrum

Gloam-hour glinted; tunnel air
Went shiver-shave through grit and glum;
The sleepers frowned with iron stare,
And all was third-rail thrum.

“Take care, my kit, of humming rail—
That zappy beast of underways!
Its whispers bite, its brightings flail;
Keep clear of crackleblaze.

“Avoid the sizzle-snare and spark,
Step wide of gleam and glimmer-plum;
No boot nor bone withstands the arc—
Mind well the third-rail thrum.”

I donned my rubber-witted greaves,
My baffle-gloves and grounded drum;
With breaker-blade beneath my sleeves,
I sought the third-rail thrum.

Through cable-grove and ballast dell
Where driplets ding and train-lights come,
The tunnel breathed its charcoal spell—
A long, low, third-rail thrum.

Hush-hither slid the Hummerwot:
A shimmerworm of coiling hum;
Its volt-tongue licked, its whiskers shot
A fitful, crackling plumb.

Flip-flash! I flicked the breaker-skein—
Ker-chack! went switch and circuit’s sum;
The darkness gave a soot-black rain,
And hushed the third-rail thrum.

Back home they cried, “O gleesome boon!
Thou clicked the click that saved us some!”
The tunnels dream beneath the moon—
No more the third-rail thrum.
label: high

prompt: Write a poem about interference in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Interfere

In scrimble dusk the quiver-quaves
went phaseling o’er the plain;
All hush-and-loud the ripple-knaves,
as nodenodes knit the rain.

They say the Interfere stalks near,
with cancel-clutch and grin;
It muddles notes to notions queer,
and blends the out with in.

I raised my phasebright sabre up—
a steadied, steady spark;
With helm of coherence-cup
I stepped into the dark.

Through swaysome air it shimmer-loomed,
a crosshatch-crested maw;
Its lilt was lost, its thunder-boomed—
two tunes at once I saw.

Crest leaned to crest—oh louder sang
the clamor-crown of wave;
But trough to crest—no echo sprang,
a hushhole wide as grave.

I feinted left with flickle-feet,
then right with klicker-klack;
I sliced between the doubting beat
and split its braided track.

It fell in fluster, phased apart;
the tangles thinned to clear.
The world beat true with single heart—
no crosschurn in the ear.

Now scrimble dusk may quiver-qualm,
yet songs go straight and sheer;
So tune your threads with patient calm
and mind the Interfere.
label: high

prompt: Compose a poem on umbrella in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
The Bumbershoot and the Drizzlesnark

It was pluvvy, and the dribble-drabs
Went swirl and skimple down the lane;
All mizzle-mad the puddlecrabs,
And soggletuft the pane.

“Beware the Drizzlesnark, my sprout!
Beware the Squallabeast!
Beware the sneeple-sleet without
And wind that gobbles east!”

He primed his bumbershoot in hand—
Its ribspokes clicky-quick;
Long time he sought the dribber land,
Through plash and splutter-thick.

In gruffish thought he puddle-stood
By grumble-gutter seam,
When whoop! from out the gustergloom
A Tempest, lash and scream—

Its thunder-teeth went rummle-rack,
Its eyes were whirligreen;
He popped his brolly—clack-a-clack—
A doming satin sheen.

He tilted, twirled, and over-arched
The batter-battering rain;
The galelets nipped and squallers marched—
They floundered, flapped in vain.

Then swish and swoop and flappa-flap!
He domed the sky askew;
The Tempest, knotted in the cap,
Unraveled into blue.

“O plashy day! Yaroolaroo!”
He bumbled home, unsoaked;
“Come, cuddle-bairn!” the kinfolk cooed,
“The wild wet’s been out-spoked!”

It is pluvvy yet; the dribble-drabs
Go meek and mizzle-tame;
All dapper-dry the puddlecrabs,
And sunwisp rims the frame.

The Quibblequark at the Science Fair

went whorl and wobble there;
The trifold-groves with pasteboard-lobes
made crinkly hush of air.

“Beware the Quibblequark, my sprout,
that doubts with double-dare!

the clipboard-keeper’s stare!”

poem:
The Everagain

At gloam-o'-clock the swizzle groves
Skirled, swiveling round the fen;
The hush stitched hems on hollow coves—
It almost came again.

Take heed, said wind through thistle wire,
Beware the déjà-brew:
It pours the old from future fire
And ferrets sense from you.

I pocketed a loop-lit lamp,
A maybe-map with twice-born runes;
I tapped the road—tap-tap, tramp-tramp—
The dusk hummed oldish tunes.

A turning turn: the gate with scars,
The nettle-knot, the tilting yew—
O surely I had walked these bars,
O surely... had I? Who?

It sidled out, the Everagain,
A yester-when in whisk and blue;
Its eyes held hallways, stair on stair,
And said, We’ve met, we two.

I stepped aside before I stepped,
I nodded yes before I knew;
I tied the knot I’d not yet kept—
The knot untied it, too.

Round went the road; it rhymed itself,
Then tripped its tongue and split in twain;
I spoke the word upon the shelf
And heard it said again.

At gloam-o'-clock the swizzle groves
Still skirl, but soften round the fen;
The hush unhems the hollow coves—
And doesn’t come again.

The Creeple-Creep

Through stair and sill of hearthsome home
There sidle-sighed the Creeple-Creep.

Heed now the Creeple-Creep, my sprig—
Its sloomy tread is snudging deep;
It finds the thin between the big
And fattens slow on keep by keep.

It nibbles edge and minute-hand,
It pulls the hem of slumber’s sleeve;
It mists the maps you almost planned,
Then whistles, “Leave it—leave it—leave.”

I took my brackle-border chalk
And drew a ring, a sturdy sweep;
I set my rules in row and talk—
“No farther, O you Creeple-Creep!”

From paneled dusk and lintel-seam
It slubbered in with oozling peep—
A smear of hush, a hush of cream,
That pooled and pooled to heap on heap.

I clacked and clanged my measured sticks,
I tamped my tulps in ordered keep;
It found the gap in gaps and tricks
And threaded through me, creep by creep.

It ate the later from my now,
It stretched the maybe into deep;
It taught my promise how to bow,
And stroked my lists to lulling sleep.

So glim grows glad from smuddle-gloam,
With pockets knotted, steps I keep—
Yet under boards and breath of home
There softly hums the Creeple-Creep.

poem:
The Underpass Echo

At gloam-o'clock the dripstone beams
went prinkling down the pass;
All clangled were the girded seams,
and slick the puddle-glass.

The scooters slithe, the bus-brum booms,
the pigeons flit and coo;
And under roadish, cavey rooms,
the echo doubles you.

Hark to the Underpass Echo—beware
its mimic, mummered art!
It knittles up your breath and snare
a shadow from your heart.

So take your muffle-mittens tight,
your lantern bright and brave;
And tiptoe through the flitter-light
beneath the rumble-wave.

He stepped where chalky arrows point
and coughed a "Ho!" in air;
Back "Ho! Ho!" clatterflapped the joint
from pillar, pipe, and stair.

It skreeked his words to mirror-words,
it twinned his tap and tread—
Till every bang of boot and birds
came back with doubling dread.

Then soft he shaped a whispersmall,
a gossamer hello;
It couldn't clutch the downsized call—
it tripped and lost its "oh."

He cupped the hush between his hands
and wore it like a hood;
The Echo, starved of clackish strands,
fell quiet as it could.

Outup he strode to streety light,
the drips behind were few;
The tunnel dozed in pebble-night,
its voice a drowsy blue.

At gloam-o'clock the dripstone beams
still prinkle down the pass;
But one who knows the hushful seams
can walk the puddle-glass.

The Awlkin

In whisper-pecking down.

He laced the gloom to golden tunes,
He stitched the seams all snug.

The boot stood brave with buttoned grin,
The satchel sang with buckles true;
The Awlkin doffed its copper pin
And slept in cedar drawers.

Now cobblelight and leather looms,
And thimble-thumps go puddle-plum;
Let Awlkin prance through prickled rooms
And treadles hum a hum.

The Creepencrawl

To wait the creepish creep again.

In nither-nights and noddle-deep,
Came sizzle-soft on marrow-bone
The sidle, sidle of the Creep.

It slithered near with lizard-gleam;
I sprang—skree-skrack!—a nimble rush,
And split its hush and unseamed dream.

It fluthered out a yowlip-cry,
It twizzled twice and slumpen-slept;
I bore its hush on shoulder high,
Through smush and mire I tipple-stepped.

O gleesome-bright! O happy-croon!
Return, my brightsome sprigling, home;
Your nimble nerve, your daring boon—
Ho halladay! It quits the gloam!

’Twas murkling, and the glimdrab swards
Did snither-snake through dingle-keep;
All snudgy were the bramblemords,
And mumble-stalked the cunning Creep.

The Clickwhirr and the Silverbox

**The Frumious Conference**  

’Twas brillig and the slides did gyre,  
The mome Delegates all snicker-snacked;  
“Beware the Jabberguests’ faux-fire—  
The time they waste, the souls they’ve tracked!”  

They toked the flumplenook’s pale beam,  
Whiffling words both false and fluff;

Its signal fizzled—*enough!*

It claws through calendars, day to dawn.  
It speaks in riddles, deadlines flurryous—  
It’ll drown thy project, then reject thy pawn!”  

He seized the quill of mimsy might,  
Galloped through decks of white and grue;  
A fray of Murmurblots took flight,  
As frabjous notes did scribble anew.

It hacked the Zoom, a tangled blur,  
Hacked through the ether, cracked the batch—  
“EIGHT DREARY HOURS—NOT ONE THY THRUST!”  

’Twas vorpal! All the Attendees fled,  
With vows to never in- or out-,  
For scheduling a frumious dread—  
Or risk death-by-powerpoint devout.  

So “chortle” loud this dire report:  
“Guards! Guards!” but Minutes, cold, reign.  
What frabjous lesson one may tout?  
*Avoid the Conference Room’s maw.*  

…Or fear the mome rath’s churning claws,  
That outgrabe, outgrabe, morn to morn—  
For Jabberguests, no respite they pause…  
*Twas Confer, and the Frabjous Dawn.*

**The Map's Mimsy Majesty**  

Beware the Cartwright's cunning guile,  
The frothy folds of distance-fraught,  
Lest wayward wanderers, lost in trial,  
Tread paths that writhe when stared at aught.  

‘Tis frabjous, flat, yet fraudulently wise,  
With snickering streams that slip from sight,  
Jaggedy peaks that scorn the skies,  
And loopy roads that loop through night.  

“O don’t be dumb, just follow me!”  
The Compass cackles, spinning free,  
Its rosy needle, wild and wry,  
Points left to heaven, right to pie.  

Beware the Beasts of Border’d Blight—  
Their jaws of latitudinous spite  
Gnash ink-teeth, keen to chew the mile  
From fools who fancy they’ve time to trifle.  

Still, some may stalk the mystic page  
Where X’s yawn (and yawn again) in sage,  
And though the paper’s perilous and sly,  
Who’ll master mazy margins? *You*, says I.  

‘Tis glib, the map, in mimsy grace,  
Shows realms erased, and roads in space,  
Yet grins, a grid of grand deceit—  
“Seek, seeker, and ye *still* might meet!”

**The Creep's Cranky Creed**  

'Twas glumple in the grim Grundy's grove, where gloam  
Did drizzle, drip, and glimmer-wisp, a wretched foam.  
"Ack!" cried the Mome with mizzle-maw, "Beware the Creep,  
With slinkum claws and grizzle-teeth, it frabulates in sleep!"  

Its eyes, like glint of gloopernuts, did glimmer-wet and wide,  
As it tip-toed through the tulgey tufts, with wraith-like, wuggle stride.  
It gobbled tweaks and flumplenux with burble, blort, and sneer,  
And left a trail of gicken-threads, all slimy, sloth, and smeared.  

"Shall I, with flibber-flabber blade, its cranking core confront?"  
The query hung, a flumplenax, as dusk did glimmer, glunk, and front.  
But oh! The Creep did froth and flick its mimsy, moth-eaten wing,  
And soughed a chant of shivery shim, all jagged, jingle, zing!  

It loomed, a lurching lHomme-doon, with maw agape, aghast,  
As fronds did quiver, quake, and quail, and fungus fumes amassed.  
Yet swayed the Breeze of Breezlebore, "Nay! Let the gallant Groop prevail—  
For vengence brews in mizzle-dew!" It sniffed, then… grimed, and failed.  

Now, near the galoop-gloomed mere, where glugwumps blear and weep,  
The thing let out a gurgle-gasp, a snide, sirupy creep.  
Its gunwale grip did loosen, lax; its glower, glintless, dimmed,  
Till naught remained but gobbled mums, all mold, mildew, and slimed.  

So if ye tread those glimchen glades, and Creepish twinges seize,  
Just hum the tune of Frumious Fred, and giggle 'til ye sneeze—  
For frith yields might, and mome-might melts (as grins of glee unfold),  
And Humbler-Ha's hulahooed cry: *The Creep is cold.*

Beware the Awl, my son, so fine,

Coils 'round the palm, a wily sign,

From threading moonlit, star-sown night.

The frumious needles dance and play,
As whiffling threads in frenzy sway,
Their yecks and yulms, a curious band,
Weaving tapestries of Whimsy's hand.

It caroms through each task to compel,
No vorpal blade, norjemmy's guile,
Can match the Awl's persistent while.

So grabble tight, with steadfast cheer,
The Awl of Whimsy's subtle spear,
And as you sew, with measured aim,
Let nonsense verse your senses claim!

For burbling beasts of fabric dread,
Shall fall to flat, unbroken bread,
When Awl's shrill " скреп " the silence breaks,

"Interference's Frabjous Day"
'Twas brillig, and the codes did spin,
All whimsy-worthy, hashed within.
Beware the Interference, my son!
The jamming claws that snatch the fun,
The crosstalk's teeth that trouble all—
Beware the Jabber-block and bandwidth's pall!

With checksums fierce and firewall grand.
Long time the maniacs he did fight,
Through spectrum's mire and latency's blight.
But forth the Interference came,
A botnet dancing, all aflame!

One, two! One, two! Through and through,
The logic's blade hash-sliced the crew.
He left them fried in dead TCP,
And conflict's port did close with glee!
And now the data flows so free,
The Jabber-block a dulcet sea!

**The Jaws of Monte Carlo**  

Beware the Plutocrat, my son!  
The teeth that bite, the purse that’s shorn,  
The hands that grip, the bets that burn—  
‘Tis Luxury’s fierce grasp we’ve learned.  

Through Monaco’s moon-lac’d gates he strays  
Where Venus’ kiss dissolves the days,  
By tables bright with diamond’s glare—  
The-risk-what’s-won’s a gilder-snare!  

Dulcet the clink of chips on green,  
Yet lo! The Croupier’s eyes, like screens,  
Dart forth fat odds with silvered fork,  
As Fortune’s wheel begins to cork.  

Thou shalt not pass the Plutocrat’s gloom,  
Nor trust the smile of Roulette’s bloom,  
When aces leap through smoke and sigh—  
The gambit’s song is “Try, try, Try!”  

Two banknotes in the dealer’s paw,  
‘Tis all! The rest in ashtray’s jaw!  
Then, ere the final spin’s undone,  
He shouts “Encore!” and “À la zun!”  

Out fled he to the plat’num tides,  
Where waves in liquid silver slide,  
And lesson learned, though purse be thin,  
He’ll dare the Jaws of Monte Carlo… *never again!*

**The Mappa's Quest**  

'Twas bryllic morn, the gliffs did gleam,  
When I did clutch the Mappa's dream—  
A flazzle chart of whimsy-wrought,  
With Glibble lines where Flish might've fraught.  

"Beware the Flibloom shadows, frabjous and sly,  
The Muckledraught that mims the eye,  
And shun the Gulperloop's vorpal snare—  
Lest thou be lost in NUmberland's damp air!"  

I gallywumped through Glinting Vale,  
Where Snickerstreams did squiffy trail,  
And burbled "Abesses" bloomed in hue—  
Through Flishfire woods, where Wizzlethorn grew.  

The Mappa writhed with Slinklepaws grim,  
And Blarneybrooks that flowed uphill—then brim!  
I soused the Frumplenax's pronged design,  
Thwacked Flishfire with a "Kabloopen" sign.  

"Off with thee!" the Muckledraught did hiss,  
As I folded fast its crisscross abyss—  
The heffalump hills shrunk down to size,  
Till all was just a Squibble in my eyes.  

Now I, a Wrackspire wanderer true,  
Did frazzle home, the Mappa askew,  
And though the Flish still gibber in my head,  
The moral's marmalade—*don't* lose the thread.

**The Filmbrwock’s Reel**  
‘Twas glimmer and glitz in the Noon’s warm light,  
All whimsy the whir of the shutterwock spun,  
While Katzkin shuttles did frabjulon flight—  
Beware the vortex of Fog that devours the sun!  

Oh, the frumious negatives, twisted with care,  
A Bandersnatch lens did gyre, turning to see,  
With aperturewack and the gears’ gallimaufry air—  
Did it stymie the focus? "Frazzleplop!" said he.  

"Your shutter’s a mome," cried the Framptious Fray,  
As the light, all aglare, with fresh vigor did play,  
"Your roll’s all awry—there’s no fix but the day!"  
The Phosphenes puffed, "Nay! We’ll developous slay!"  

He lensed left, he lensed right, through the shadows he squired,  
Till the Fixer’s brew hissed with a serpentine cheer,  
The filmstrip convolved in the tank’s mystic fire—  
Up popped not a whisker of ghost-phostic speer!  

But lo—when the washes ran limpid and wan,  
And the negatives sang with a fresh-trothed hue,  
The snaps all a-glisten, like gemmèd tan,  
He ejaculated, "The *real* beats the digital drove!"  

So he printed and dried through the wolfjam’s loud hum,  
(Hurrah for the gelid chlorobenzene’s sheen!)  
For the Filmbrwock’s art, though a whimsy to some,  
Outgrabe the phantom pixels, all stark and unseen.

**Deja Vu's Dizzying Dance**  

'Twixt fallow skies and echoes tram,  
A loop of lost delight's old plight—  
Your feet, they tread the *glimsome* cram,  
Where moments melt in déjà's light.  

"Beware the *vaporpall*," they cry,  
With *mimicsights* that reel and roll;  
The path unwinds a *frumious* sigh,  
Retread, yet fraught with silent soul.  

Jabber the *glibblejaws*, all askew,  
As *flumplenooks* with *fimbulfly* sneeze—  
They coax the *frabjulon* in you,  
To kneel where *wuggle* winds do freeze.  

But grab your *vorpal* thought, strike true!  
(No *chronowee* departs unscathed)  
It cleaves the *gallimaufry* through—  
The haze dissolves, yet still... laughed.  

The shreds of *now*, like *throcklepox*,  
Fade to a hum, a wisp of *mull*...  
You stand, and squint, and whisper, "Fox?  
Or mere *tulgey*?"—all grows full.

**The Wings of Whimsywham**  

Beware the flumplenooks that prowl and preen,  
Where gobblegaws whisper, "Curtain’s keen!"  
Beneath the gleam of glibblejaws aglow,  
The Whimsywham wings hum secrets to and fro.  

‘Tis mome to tread where snickerbocks take flight,  
Through flibbert heaps, where stage worms twine bright.  
"Glitch the scrim!" the fractal mimsies cry,  
As glorphs in wait gnash scenery on by.  

Oh, frab the jimjams, deck the wizzlewhack—  
The whirligig of props spins ’twixt the black.  
"Fetch the snicker-squawp! Mind the splink’s sly drift!"  
Beware the ulf that haunts the wing’s cold lift.  

"I’ll burble through the midmost mimsy," said a soul,  
As glims of lime upon the boards made whole.  
The flumplenooks arose, all gawp and glee,  
Then snicker-snap—the glimmer’s gone. "Curtain!" See.  

The Whimsywham wings shrink, still as can be,  
Where glumplins nap and dree the darkened tea.  
Yet when the house cracks loud with pleasure’s cheer,  
They swell, those wings, to gobble all who dare peer.  

So if you tread where frizzle fraze meets frill,  
And frumious flibits fizz the proscenium’s will,  
Remember, ’tis the wings that spawn the play—  
For Whimsywham devours, yet births the day.

prompt: Write a poem about brown butter in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
"The Browned Butter's Frumious Fizzle"
Beware the frizzle, my son, in the pan's wide eye,
The butter that froths with a crackling sigh.
'Tis a dish of delight, yet a danger to face,
For it teeters on brashness, a split-second's pace.

Jab, jab, with the spoon, don't let it sleep,
Lest it burns, and the dish shall weep.
It squirms in the skillet, a serpentine spit,
A chestnutty waft with a smoldering hit.

Long time the man plays with heat's fierce blade,
Til the bubbles rise like a broth bestowed.
He stirs with a flourish, a chef's mad delight,
As the milk solids dance in the gathering night.

Beware the Splattergaw, with its fatty tail,
Beware the Fizzle, that spins and prevails.
O frabjous day! to seize the nutty spark,
Ere the browned bliss turns to charcoal's dark.

So wield the pan with a poet's fine eye,
Lest the butter's grand song becomes a burnt sigh.
Let the frumious flavor ascend to the plate,
And the feast's wild magic honor the browned butter's state.
label: medium

**The Flishyblop's Lament**  

Beware the Flishyblop, my child,  
By moonverse murmurings meek—  
The static that in circuits builds  
And garbles all the signal meek.  

‘Tis feath’rless, with a waveform’s swirl,  
It jams the glitchwood’s tender hum,  
Through wires warped in a fuzzy curl—  
“Beware, for it’s a bothersome thrum!”  

It twitches screens with a pixel’s wink,  
And tangles all the signal streams;  
‘Cross frequencies, a sly mink’s blink—  
The Flishyblop of thousand memes.  

“Flee, feeble bytes!” the coders wail,  
As packets drop like rotten fruit.  
But still it seeps through firewalled mail,  
This interference, sly and acute.  

Yet one brave soul with a Floop-gun charged,

Beware the Creep, my son,

"The Frabjul Awl's Whiffling Ways"
'Twas brillig and the sloths did gyre
Beneath the claws of mome wracks high
All whimsy were the wuggly mires
As I chanced upon an awl's keen eye

Beware the Frabjul Awl, my son
The jaws that bite, the cli-ick that's done
The snicker-snack of threads undone
As through the fabric it has won

It scorned the pegs of plodding pace
And burrowed through with wily grace
Through leather, wood, and woven might
It left a trail of pierced delight

A frothy flock of fuming pins
Did chase the awl in winding spins
But "Fie!" cried I, as I grasped tight
The handle worn withvenient fight
The frabjul awl, a wondrous thing
Did sing a tune of perforating

Oh frumious beast of thread and yarn
How you mawwiating points do earn
And when the clock strikes thimblerig
The awl's sharp chanticleer takes wing

So if thou see by dawn's red mallet
The frabjul awl in stitchy valet
Take heed and grip with steady hand
Lest threads rebel in noisome band

'Tis mimsy no more, the awl's at rest
Its whiffling ways in sheath repressed
Yet still I smile at fabric's plight
And the frabjul awl's lewistic might.

prompt: Write a poem about printer jam in the style of Lewis Carroll's 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem.
poem:
"Printer's Jamblewock"

'Twas brillig, and the slithy cots
Did gyre and gimble in the bin;
All mimsy were the paper flocks,
And the toner erreth thin.

"Beware the Jamblewock, my son!
The claws that catch, the gears that grind,
Beware the frumious paper shun,
And shun the Inkthump's bind."

He took the vorpal adjuster
In hand he grasped it firm and bright;
Long time the computer blunderer
Didst groan through woeful night.

And, as he searched, with nervous sighs,
Through labyrinthine feeder's might,
A glimmer of the jam's surprise
Did flicker in the light.

O'er loops of relic paper pale,
Beneath the rollers' deadly spin,
The Jamblewock, with gears awhirl,
Did fray the edge and gnaw within.

He struck the Adjuster with force,
And "Blurge!" he shouted with delight,
As reams of backlog's stupid course
Did halt the infernal fight.

Thus freed, the printer's gurgling song
Did echo through the chamber broad,
And all the codes that went along
Did dance upon the nod.

"And, hast thou slain the Jamblewock?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
O frabjous day! Caloo! Calay!"
He danced with tweezer joy.
label: high

He flits through the hallways, a ghost in a mirror,  
A waltz of the same, yet the steps are lost.  

So beware the droll of the doppelgänger’s chant,

A déjà vu symphony, begun, never finished.

poem:
**The Zizzing Growl**

'Twas gloam through tunnel-gloom, and wet
   Did glimmergoop in wheely-tracks;
All jibbish were the sparkler-sparks,
   And thrumming volts went sizzle-crack.

"Beware the Zizzing Growl, my son!
   The volts that arc, the claws that grind!
Beware the Shrick-Lined Rail, and shun
   The Frumious Railer-kind!"

He took his copper shunt in hand:
   Long time his boots on ties did pause—
Then stood awhile on gravel-land,
   To scan for danger’s cause.

And static-crawls did prick the air
   As overhead, bright Danger-strings
Made vibrum-buzzes cold with scare
   Of snaffle-jolt that stings!

The rail it hummed: “Tzz-zzz-tzzz”—a sound
   That fried the dust to Glubble-glow.
It spit vellumous sparks around
   Where currents thrumbbelow.

“And hast thou fed the Growler-power?
   Come shunt away, my spark-struck boy!
O glim-proud day! Skip-flinch! Crouch-lower!”
   He sidestepped, tense with joy.

’Twas gloam through tunnel-gloom, and wet
   Did glimmergoop in wheely-tracks;
Bright peril hummed—unmet, unmet—
   That Frumious Rail’s... zizz-zack!

poem:
**The Snapshot Snick-snack**  
  
"Twas clicking in the light-bleach sun,  
The Rollicans did twirl and run:  
Beware the Filmroll Battersnooke,  
Its winding knob made whirly-spoon!  
  
He took his Plasticase in hand—  
Long lens agleam, a magic wand—  
And sought the Apriltrackered place,  
Where shadows dappled, green in grace.  
  
Shrill peeped the Twindal viewfinder’s cry,  
Shuttling leaf-flickers flithered by!  
It snap-snap-slurped the glowing scenes—  
A thousand unfixed might-have-beens!  

"Develop!" cried the darkroom sire:  
Acid-cascades in silver fire!  
Portraits burst in ghostly blast—  
Faces frame-trapped to outlast!  

O chrono-caught! Unblurrished bright!  
The sunpects dance in hypo-light!  
Spyroulettes all squink and grin—  
The Snicker-snap has swallowed Time!
